I Self-consistent determination of the final state resulting from aging of a quenched liquid

Numerical estimates for all of the features on the phase diagram of a quenched liquid were obtained for monodisperse hard spheres as the model system. For the sc>0subscript𝑠𝑐0s_{c}>0 part of the equilibrium EOS, we use the Percus Yevick equation of state:

p~PY​(φ)≡pρ​kB​T=1+φ+φ2(1−φ)3.subscript~𝑝PY𝜑𝑝𝜌subscript𝑘𝐵𝑇1𝜑superscript𝜑2superscript1𝜑3\tilde{p}_{\text{PY}}(\varphi)\equiv\frac{p}{\rho k_{B}T}=\frac{1+\varphi+\varphi^{2}}{(1-\varphi)^{3}}. (S1)

For configurational adiabats, we use the Salsburg-Wood form

p~SW​(φ,φmax)=3φmax/φ−1+1,subscript~𝑝SW𝜑subscript𝜑max3subscript𝜑max𝜑11\tilde{p}_{\text{SW}}(\varphi,\varphi_{\text{max}})=\frac{3}{\varphi_{\text{max}}/\varphi-1}+1, (S2)

given as Eq. (7) in the main text. The sc=0subscript𝑠𝑐0s_{c}=0 part of the equilibrium EOS is given by Eq. (S2) with φmax=φK∞​0.64subscript𝜑maxsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾0.64\varphi_{\text{max}}=\varphi_{K}^{\infty}0.64. Configurationally adiabatic quenches are assumed to be SW isotherms, whose φmax≤φK∞subscript𝜑maxsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾\varphi_{\text{max}}\leq\varphi_{K}^{\infty}, of course. According to Rabochiy and Lubchenko, Rabochiy and Lubchenko (2012a) (RL) the filling fraction at the crossover is φ=0.47𝜑0.47\varphi=0.47, which may well be an underestimate: The filling fraction at the melting point, according to simulation, Hoover and Ree (1968) is 0.490.490.49. The reason for this likely underestimate is RL’s using the Bennett lattice Bennett (1973) in their DFT calculation. This does not pose significant issues, however, as long as we use the very same DFT setup for the rest of the quantities. Just such data are available thanks to Löwen, Lowen (1990) who reports the elastic constants as functions of the filling fraction for an aperiodic crystal state. For instance, at the crossover, he obtains K~=29.8~𝐾29.8\widetilde{K}=29.8 and μ~=24.9~𝜇24.9\widetilde{\mu}=24.9. Thus we adopt μ/K=24.9/29.8𝜇𝐾24.929.8\mu/K=24.9/29.8 independent of density and pressure.

With the above in mind, Eqs. (10), (11) and (12) yield the following system of equations that needs to be solved to determine self-consistently the density φeqsubscript𝜑eq\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}} and pressure p~eqsubscript~𝑝eq\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}} of the aged region, if the initial, quenched state was at density φ𝜑\varphi and pressure p𝑝p:

φ​p~−φeq​p~eq𝜑~𝑝subscript𝜑eqsubscript~𝑝eq\displaystyle\varphi\tilde{p}-\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}} =(φeq−φ)​K~eq​2​(1−2​σ)1+σabsentsubscript𝜑eq𝜑subscript~𝐾eq212𝜎1𝜎\displaystyle=(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-\varphi)\>\widetilde{K}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\>\frac{2(1-2\sigma)}{1+\sigma} (S3)
p~~𝑝\displaystyle\tilde{p} =p~SW​(φ,φmax)absentsubscript~𝑝SW𝜑subscript𝜑max\displaystyle=\tilde{p}_{\text{SW}}(\varphi,\varphi_{\text{max}}) (S4)
p~eqsubscript~𝑝eq\displaystyle\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}} ={p~PY​(φeq),φeq≤φKp~SW​(φeq,φK∞),φeq>φKabsentcasessubscript~𝑝PYsubscript𝜑eqsubscript𝜑eqsubscript𝜑𝐾subscript~𝑝SWsubscript𝜑eqsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾subscript𝜑eqsubscript𝜑𝐾\displaystyle=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\tilde{p}_{\text{PY}}(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}),&\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\leq\varphi_{K}\\ \tilde{p}_{\text{SW}}(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}},\varphi_{K}^{\infty}),&\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}>\varphi_{K}\end{array}\right. (S7)

Here, the density of the Kauzmann state φKsubscript𝜑𝐾\varphi_{K} is defined as the intersection of the sc>0subscript𝑠𝑐0s_{c}>0 and sc=0subscript𝑠𝑐0s_{c}=0 parts of the equilibrium EOS. The reduced bulk modulus of the aged states, K~~𝐾\widetilde{K}, is computed by differentiating the configurational adiabat p​(φ)𝑝𝜑p(\varphi) at the target state and depends only on the density of the latter:

K~eq≡∂∂φ[φp~SW(φ,φmax∗))]|φ=φeq,\widetilde{K}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\equiv\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial\varphi}[\varphi\>\tilde{p}_{\text{SW}}(\varphi,\varphi_{\text{max}}^{*}))]\right|_{\varphi=\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}}, (S8)

where the maximum attainable density φ∗superscript𝜑\varphi^{*} along the pertinent SW isotherm is determined by equating the latter with the PY isotherm:

p~SW​(φeq,φmax∗)=p~PY​(φeq).subscript~𝑝SWsubscript𝜑eqsuperscriptsubscript𝜑maxsubscript~𝑝PYsubscript𝜑eq\tilde{p}_{\text{SW}}(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}},\varphi_{\text{max}}^{*})=\tilde{p}_{\text{PY}}(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}). (S9)

As a practical matter, it is much more convenient to determine φ𝜑\varphi as a function of φeqsubscript𝜑eq\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}} than the other way around because (a): the SW isotherm affords one to explicitly write out φ𝜑\varphi and φmaxsubscript𝜑max\varphi_{\text{max}} as functions of p~~𝑝\tilde{p} and (b): the equilibrium EOS is only piece-wise smooth and experiences a slope discontinuity. The so obtained families of φ𝜑\varphi corresponding with five particular values of φeqsubscript𝜑eq\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}} are shown in Fig. 4 of the main text using thin lines with arrows.

To obtain Eq. (21), which we replicate here:

φmax∗​p~−φK∞​p~eq=p~eq2​A​(φK∞−φmax∗)​2​(1−2​σ)1+σ,superscriptsubscript𝜑max~𝑝superscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾subscript~𝑝eqsuperscriptsubscript~𝑝eq2𝐴superscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜑max212𝜎1𝜎\varphi_{\text{max}}^{*}\tilde{p}-\varphi_{K}^{\infty}\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}=\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}^{2}\>A(\varphi_{K}^{\infty}-\varphi_{\text{max}}^{*})\>\frac{2(1-2\sigma)}{1+\sigma}, (S10)

we use Eq. (S3) and note that in the p~,p~eq→∞→~𝑝subscript~𝑝eq\tilde{p},\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\to\infty limit, one has φ→φmax∗→𝜑superscriptsubscript𝜑max\varphi\to\varphi_{\text{max}}^{*}, φeq→φK∞→subscript𝜑eqsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\to\varphi_{K}^{\infty}, and the asymptotic expression in Eq. (4) applies. Clearly, the term φK∞​p~eqsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾subscript~𝑝eq\varphi_{K}^{\infty}\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}} in the l.h.s. can be neglected in this limit because p~eq∝p~1/2proportional-tosubscript~𝑝eqsuperscript~𝑝12\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\propto\tilde{p}^{1/2}, as pointed out in the main text. Consequently, one gets Δ​g/kB​T→−p~→Δ𝑔subscript𝑘𝐵𝑇~𝑝\Delta g/k_{B}T\to-\tilde{p}, and so Eqs. (16) and (S3) yield Eq. (20) of the main text. Note that the asterisk at φmax∗superscriptsubscript𝜑max\varphi_{\text{max}}^{*} is dropped there, without risk of confusion, to reduce cluttering.

II Determination of the slope of the spinodal line near the equilibrium crossover

It is instructive to ask whether the slope of the string spinodal is greater or less that the slope of the configurational adiabat, near the equilibrium crossover (φcr,pcr−1)subscript𝜑crsuperscriptsubscript𝑝cr1(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize cr}},p_{\mbox{\scriptsize cr}}^{-1}). More specifically, we wish to determine whether or not one will encounter the string spinodal for conventional quenches starting below the equilibrium crossover, which approximately follow configurational adiabats. To settle this, we need to calculate the (logarithmic) slope of the crossover line,

Ks≡(∂p/∂ln⁡φ)p=ps​(φ),subscript𝐾𝑠subscript𝑝𝜑𝑝subscript𝑝𝑠𝜑K_{s}\equiv(\partial p/\partial\ln\varphi)_{p=p_{s}(\varphi)}, (S11)

near the equilibrium crossover pcr,eqsubscript𝑝creqp_{{\mbox{\scriptsize cr}},{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}}, where ps​(φ)subscript𝑝𝑠𝜑p_{s}(\varphi) is the pressure vs. density dependence specifying the string-spinodal line.

Consider an infinitesimally shallow quenching protocol depicted in Fig. S1 so that the changes in the filling fraction and pressure are all infinitesimally small. Denote the “direction” of the quench with Kqsubscript𝐾𝑞K_{q} so that

Kq=φ​p−p1φ−φ1,subscript𝐾𝑞𝜑𝑝subscript𝑝1𝜑subscript𝜑1K_{q}=\varphi\>\frac{p-p_{1}}{\varphi-\varphi_{1}}, (S12)

where p1subscript𝑝1p_{1} is the starting value of pressure. The value peqsubscript𝑝eqp_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}} of the pressure following relaxation from the quenched state at pressure p𝑝p is determined by the condition from the main text’s Eq. (10):

p−peq=φeq−φφ​4​μ3.𝑝subscript𝑝eqsubscript𝜑eq𝜑𝜑4𝜇3p-p_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}=\frac{\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-\varphi}{\varphi}\>\frac{4\mu}{3}. (S13)

Both point 1 and the equilibrated states belong to the equilibrium EOS,

K=φ​peq−p1φeq−φ1,𝐾𝜑subscript𝑝eqsubscript𝑝1subscript𝜑eqsubscript𝜑1K=\varphi\>\frac{p_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-p_{1}}{\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-\varphi_{1}}, (S14)

where K𝐾K is the equilibrium bulk modulus. Using Eqs. (S12) and (S14), one can rewrite Eq. (S13) as

(φ−φ1)​K~q−(φeq−φ1)​K~=φeq−φφ​4​μ~3,𝜑subscript𝜑1subscript~𝐾𝑞subscript𝜑eqsubscript𝜑1~𝐾subscript𝜑eq𝜑𝜑4~𝜇3(\varphi-\varphi_{1})\widetilde{K}_{q}-(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-\varphi_{1})\widetilde{K}=\frac{\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-\varphi}{\varphi}\>\frac{4\widetilde{\mu}}{3}, (S15)

where we have used that all Δ​φΔ𝜑\Delta\varphi’s and Δ​pΔ𝑝\Delta p’s are infinitesimally small.

To determine the slope of the crossover line near the equilibrium EOS, we place state 1 exactly at the equilibrium crossover and set p(s)=psuperscript𝑝(s)𝑝p^{\text{(s)}}=p in Eq. (26) of the main text:

p/ρ−peq/ρeq=[γ~′−sc/kB+ln⁡Ω+Δ​svibr]​kB​T.𝑝𝜌subscript𝑝eqsubscript𝜌eqdelimited-[]superscript~𝛾′subscript𝑠𝑐subscript𝑘𝐵ΩΔsubscript𝑠vibrsubscript𝑘𝐵𝑇p/\rho-p_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}/\rho_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}=[\tilde{\gamma}^{\prime}-s_{c}/k_{B}+\ln\Omega+\Delta s_{\mbox{\scriptsize vibr}}]k_{B}T. (S16)

Noting that the r.h.s. in the above equation is equal to zero at the crossover, the latter equation can be rewritten as:

(φ−φ1)​K~q−(φeq−φ1)​K~=(φeq−φ1)​K~​B,𝜑subscript𝜑1subscript~𝐾𝑞subscript𝜑eqsubscript𝜑1~𝐾subscript𝜑eqsubscript𝜑1~𝐾𝐵(\varphi-\varphi_{1})\widetilde{K}_{q}-(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-\varphi_{1})\widetilde{K}=(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-\varphi_{1})\widetilde{K}\>B, (S17)

up to Δ​φ2Δsuperscript𝜑2\Delta\varphi^{2}, where

B≡K~−1​{p~+∂ln⁡φ​[γ~′−(sc/kB+ln⁡Ω+Δ​svibr)]}.𝐵superscript~𝐾1~𝑝𝜑delimited-[]superscript~𝛾′subscript𝑠𝑐subscript𝑘𝐵ΩΔsubscript𝑠vibrB\equiv\widetilde{K}^{-1}\left\{\tilde{p}+\frac{\partial}{\ln\varphi}[\tilde{\gamma}^{\prime}-(s_{c}/k_{B}+\ln\Omega+\Delta s_{\mbox{\scriptsize vibr}})]\right\}. (S18)

Upon setting Ks=Kqsubscript𝐾𝑠subscript𝐾𝑞K_{s}=K_{q} Eqs. (S15) and (S17) yield

Ks=1+B1−3​K4​μ​B​K,subscript𝐾𝑠1𝐵13𝐾4𝜇𝐵𝐾K_{s}=\frac{1+B}{1-\frac{3K}{4\mu}B}\>K, (S19)

We now discuss of Eq. (S19) in the context of conventional glass-formers made of chemical compounds. Since the ratio 3​K/4​μ3𝐾4𝜇3K/4\mu is numerically close to unity for most such systems, the question of the slope of the crossover line, near the equilibrium EOS, largely reduces to establishing the value of the dimensionless quantity B𝐵B. To take advantage of available data for volume dependence of the bulk modulus, as in Ref. Soma, 1980, and using Eqs. (9) and (24), we rewrite Eq. (S18) as

B=cγ2​K~1/2​∂ln⁡K∂ln⁡φ+1K~​[p~−∂ln⁡φ​(sc/kB+ln⁡Ω+Δ​svibr)].𝐵subscript𝑐𝛾2superscript~𝐾12𝐾𝜑1~𝐾delimited-[]~𝑝𝜑subscript𝑠𝑐subscript𝑘𝐵ΩΔsubscript𝑠vibrB=\frac{c_{\gamma}}{2\widetilde{K}^{1/2}}\frac{\partial\ln K}{\partial\ln\varphi}+\frac{1}{\widetilde{K}}\left[\tilde{p}-\frac{\partial}{\ln\varphi}(s_{c}/k_{B}+\ln\Omega+\Delta s_{\mbox{\scriptsize vibr}})\right]. (S20)

According to the compilation of data for crystalline alkaline metals by Soma, Soma (1980) the dimensionless quantity ∂ln⁡K/∂ln⁡φ𝐾𝜑\partial\ln K/\partial\ln\varphi exceeds unity but not by very much. We adopt ∂ln⁡K/∂ln⁡φ=3𝐾𝜑3\partial\ln K/\partial\ln\varphi=3, based on Fig. 11 of Ref. Soma, 1980 for concreteness. The value of the reduced bulk modulus at the crossover can be estimated using Rabochiy and Lubchenko’s result Rabochiy and Lubchenko (2012b) that at the crossover,

μ~cr≈5.8​5−6​σ2​(1−σ),subscript~𝜇cr5.856𝜎21𝜎\widetilde{\mu}_{\mbox{\scriptsize cr}}\approx 5.8\>\frac{5-6\sigma}{2(1-\sigma)}, (S21)

where 5.85.85.8 is a numerical constant. Note the fraction varies relatively little for 0<σ<1/20𝜎120<\sigma<1/2, viz., between 2 and 2.5. Considering that cγ≃1/2similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑐𝛾12c_{\gamma}\simeq 1/2, one gets for the first term in Eq. (S20) a numerical value of 0.2 or so.

Next, the ratio p~/K~𝑝𝐾\tilde{p}/K is bounded from above by its value for hard spheres, viz., ca. one-tenth but is much much smaller for soft spheres and can be neglected, according to the discussion in then main text. The rate of the decrease of the configurational entropy, ∂sc/∂ln⁡φsubscript𝑠𝑐𝜑\partial s_{c}/\partial\ln\varphi is about 10​kB10subscript𝑘𝐵10k_{B}. Rabochiy and Lubchenko (2012a) The latter value specifically gives excellent agreement for the relation between the fragility coefficients at constant pressure and volume, Rabochiy and Lubchenko (2012a) respectively, and will be adopted here for actual glassformers. A sense for the magnitude ∂sc/ln⁡φ≃10​kBsimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑠𝑐𝜑10subscript𝑘𝐵\partial s_{c}/\ln\varphi\simeq 10k_{B} can be obtained by noting that known glassforming liquids decrease in volume following crystallization. The entropy of fusion is roughly 1​kB1subscript𝑘𝐵1k_{B} per particle while the volume change is about 10%. Thus this term contributes one third or so. We do not know how to estimate the rate of change of the “string entropy” ln⁡ΩΩ\ln\Omega, however note that ln⁡ΩΩ\ln\Omega goes roughly as the log number of nearest neighbors. The latter quantity is expected to change with density much less than scsubscript𝑠𝑐s_{c}; we will assume it does not vary. The term −K~−1​∂ln⁡φ​Δ​svibrsuperscript~𝐾1𝜑Δsubscript𝑠vibr-\widetilde{K}^{-1}\frac{\partial}{\ln\varphi}\Delta s_{\mbox{\scriptsize vibr}} is bounded from above by its value for hard spheres, 3/p~3~𝑝3/\tilde{p}, which is numerically about one third.

One thus obtains that the quantity B𝐵B is probably less than one but not by much: B≈0.6​…​0.9𝐵0.6…0.9B\approx 0.6\ldots 0.9. At the same time, the ratio 3​K/4​μ=(1+σ)/2​(1−2​σ)3𝐾4𝜇1𝜎212𝜎3K/4\mu=(1+\sigma)/2(1-2\sigma) varies between 1 and 4 or so in the generic σ𝜎\sigma range 0.2​…​0.40.2…0.40.2\ldots 0.4, Mott and Roland (2009) the lower limit more likely than the latter. Thus we obtain that the ratio Ks/KTsubscript𝐾𝑠subscript𝐾𝑇K_{s}/K_{T} is of order ten, i.e., significantly exceeds one, but could be significantly higher and even negative. These qualitative estimates thus suggest that the string spinodal runs well below the configurational adiabat originating at the crossover and could even bend toward lower densities.

III High pressure asymptotics of the string spinodal

Eq. (21) implies that at high pressures and a finite Δ​φΔ𝜑\Delta\varphi, peq∝p1/2proportional-tosubscript𝑝eqsuperscript𝑝12p_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\propto p^{1/2}, as pointed out in the main text. This is incompatible with Eq. (26), because γ′∝γ∝peqproportional-tosuperscript𝛾′𝛾proportional-tosubscript𝑝eq\gamma^{\prime}\propto\gamma\propto p_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}. Thus, the spinodal line must reach the fully compressed Kauzmann state in the p→∞→𝑝p\to\infty limit: φ→φK∞→𝜑superscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾\varphi\to\varphi_{K}^{\infty}. (A fortiori, φeq→φK∞→subscript𝜑eqsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\to\varphi_{K}^{\infty}.) Under these circumstances, Eq. (S3) yields:

p~−p~eq=φeq−φφK∞​K~eq​2​(1−2​σ)1+σ,~𝑝subscript~𝑝eqsubscript𝜑eq𝜑superscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾subscript~𝐾eq212𝜎1𝜎\tilde{p}-\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}=\frac{\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-\varphi}{\varphi_{K}^{\infty}}\>\widetilde{K}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}\>\frac{2(1-2\sigma)}{1+\sigma}, (S22)

while Eqs. (26), (9) and (24) imply

p~−p~eq=cγ​K~eq1/2.~𝑝subscript~𝑝eqsubscript𝑐𝛾superscriptsubscript~𝐾eq12\tilde{p}-\tilde{p}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}=c_{\gamma}\widetilde{K}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}^{1/2}. (S23)

Equating the right-hand-sides of Eqs. (S22) and (S23), together with the high-pressure limit of the SW isotherm,

K~eq=3​(φK∞)2(φK∞−φeq)2,subscript~𝐾eq3superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾subscript𝜑eq2\widetilde{K}_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}=\frac{3(\varphi_{K}^{\infty})^{2}}{(\varphi_{K}^{\infty}-\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}})^{2}}, (S24)

immediately makes it clear that the density change for an aging event starting at the spinodal, in the p→∞→𝑝p\to\infty limit, is proportional to the proximity of the equilibrium state to the infinitely compressed Kauzmann state: (φeq−φ)∝(φK∞−φeq)proportional-tosubscript𝜑eq𝜑superscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾subscript𝜑eq(\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}-\varphi)\propto(\varphi_{K}^{\infty}-\varphi_{\mbox{\scriptsize eq}}). That is, the p→∞→𝑝p\to\infty end of the spinodal line is at the infinitely compressed Kauzmann state. Finally, by employing the SW equation of state, one readily obtains:

p~−1=(φK∞−φ)​[φK∞​(cγ/c1​31/2+1)​(3+cγ​31/2)]−1,superscript~𝑝1superscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾𝜑superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾subscript𝑐𝛾subscript𝑐1superscript31213subscript𝑐𝛾superscript3121\tilde{p}^{-1}=(\varphi_{K}^{\infty}-\varphi)\left[\varphi_{K}^{\infty}\left(c_{\gamma}/c_{1}3^{1/2}+1\right)\left(3+c_{\gamma}3^{1/2}\right)\right]^{-1}, (S25)

where

c1≡2​(1−2​σ)1+σ.subscript𝑐1212𝜎1𝜎c_{1}\equiv\frac{2(1-2\sigma)}{1+\sigma}. (S26)

Clearly the linear dependence specified by Eq. (S25) has a smaller slope than that of the Kauzmann line near p−1=0superscript𝑝10p^{-1}=0. The latter line is given by p~−1=(φK∞−φ)/3​φK∞superscript~𝑝1superscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾𝜑3superscriptsubscript𝜑𝐾\tilde{p}^{-1}=(\varphi_{K}^{\infty}-\varphi)/3\varphi_{K}^{\infty}, according to Eq. (S2).

IV The buckling instability

Here we discuss in some detail another, significantly milder type of instability that could take place in a compressed aperiodic crystal. The onset of symmetry breaking and, hence, marginal stability will take place just when the two sides of the elongated cage in Fig. 7(b) become distinguishable. Since the coordinate of a particle can be specified only within its vibrational displacement, α−1/2superscript𝛼12\alpha^{-1/2}, one may restate the latter notion more formally in the form of the following criterion: The symmetry breaking will occur when the difference in the vibrational displacement between a long and short axis of the cage exceeds the typical displacement:

δ​(α−1/2)>α−1/2.𝛿superscript𝛼12superscript𝛼12\delta(\alpha^{-1/2})>\alpha^{-1/2}. (S27)

Below the crossover, when the cages are relatively stable and isotropic, the material behaves locally like an elastic solid. Under these circumstances, the l.h.s. is essentially the deviation of the aspect ratio of the cage from unity, times the lattice spacing. The latter deviation, in turn, can be thought of as a frozen-in fluctuation of shear. Bevzenko and Lubchenko (2009, 2014) The magnitude of the typical strength of local fluctuations of shear can be estimated using continuum mechanics, by which the shear part of the free energy is given by Landau and Lifshitz (1986) ∫𝑑V​μ​(ui​k−δi​k​uj​j)2differential-d𝑉𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖𝑘subscript𝑢𝑗𝑗2\int dV\mu(u_{ik}-\delta_{ik}u_{jj})^{2}, where ui​ksubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘u_{ik} is the strain tensor and μ𝜇\mu the shear modulus. Note the traceless tensor (ui​k−δi​k​uj​j)subscript𝑢𝑖𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖𝑘subscript𝑢𝑗𝑗(u_{ik}-\delta_{ik}u_{jj}) exclusively reflects the shear component of the strain. Hence we adopt δ​(α−1/2)≃⟨(ui​k−δi​k​uj​j)2⟩1/2similar-to-or-equals𝛿superscript𝛼12superscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖𝑘subscript𝑢𝑗𝑗212\delta(\alpha^{-1/2})\simeq\left\langle(u_{ik}-\delta_{ik}u_{jj})^{2}\right\rangle^{1/2}. Since shear is responsible for two degrees of freedom, the latter free energy will typically fluctuate by kB​Tsubscript𝑘𝐵𝑇k_{B}T, yielding:

δ​(α−1/2)≃a​(kB​Tf/μf​V)1/2,similar-to-or-equals𝛿superscript𝛼12𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑘𝐵subscript𝑇𝑓subscript𝜇𝑓𝑉12\delta(\alpha^{-1/2})\simeq a(k_{B}T_{f}/\mu_{f}V)^{1/2}, (S28)

where μfsubscript𝜇𝑓\mu_{f} and Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f} stand, respectively, for the shear modulus and temperature at the beginning of the quench. The label “f𝑓f” refers to “fictive,” in deference to the terminology accepted in the field of glass aging. Note that for compression-induced quenches, Tfsubscript𝑇𝑓T_{f} is equal to the ambient temperature T𝑇T, by construction. For a cage formed by the first coordination shell, the pertinent volume V𝑉V can be estimated as (4​π/3)​(3​a/2)34𝜋3superscript3𝑎23(4\pi/3)(3a/2)^{3}, where a𝑎a is the volumetric size of a rigid molecular unit that is not significantly perturbed by liquid motions, or “bead.” Lubchenko and Wolynes (2003a) At the same time, the typical vibrational displacement in our solid, i.e. the r.h.s. of Eq. (S27), can be estimated using the equipartition theorem. For temperature well above the Debye temperature TDsubscript𝑇𝐷T_{D} the displacement is thus simply given by the quantity (kB​T/K​a3)1/2superscriptsubscript𝑘𝐵𝑇𝐾superscript𝑎312(k_{B}T/Ka^{3})^{1/2} but should saturate at (kB​TD/K​a3)1/2superscriptsubscript𝑘𝐵subscript𝑇𝐷𝐾superscript𝑎312(k_{B}T_{D}/Ka^{3})^{1/2} with lowering the temperature. With these notions in mind, we can rewrite Eq. (S27) as

kB​Tf​ρfμf>9​π2​max⁡(kB​T​ρK,kB​TD​ρK)α≫1,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑘𝐵subscript𝑇𝑓subscript𝜌𝑓subscript𝜇𝑓9𝜋2subscript𝑘𝐵𝑇𝜌𝐾subscript𝑘𝐵subscript𝑇𝐷𝜌𝐾much-greater-than𝛼1\frac{k_{B}T_{f}\rho_{f}}{\mu_{f}}>\frac{9\pi}{2}\>\max\left(\frac{k_{B}T\rho}{K},\frac{k_{B}T_{D}\rho}{K}\right)\hskip 14.22636pt\alpha\gg 1, (S29)

where, note, the bulk modulus K𝐾K and density ρ𝜌\rho are temperature/pressure dependent. In view of the facts that 9​π/2≈149𝜋2149\pi/2\approx 14 and that the bulk and shear modulus for most substances are numerically similar, the above condition can be satisfied only if one can achieve a very substantial increase in the bulk modulus by quenching.

That the condition (S29) cannot be realized in conventional glassformers is brought home by the empirical notion that the Debye temperature in the latter materials is correlated with the melting temperature Grimvall and Sjödin (1974) and, hence, the glass transition temperature, Wang et al. (2006); Lubchenko and Wolynes (2003a) so as not be less than a quarter of the glass transition temperature, if not more. At the same time, the elastic constants of solids increase only modestly upon cooling at constant pressure. Rabochiy et al. (2013); Lubchenko and Rabochiy (2014) Thus we conclude that in conventional glassformers made by thermally quenching from the aperiodic crystal significantly below Tcrsubscript𝑇crT_{\mbox{\scriptsize cr}}, quantum fluctuations will destroy the type of symmetry breaking associated with the anisotropy of the immediate coordination shell. In physical terms, this simply means that because of the softness of inter-atomic interactions, local idiosyncrasies in the coordination shell are effectively averaged over as a result of vibrations. Pressure induced quenches are much harder to realize in conventional glassformers and are performed relatively rarely. Casalini and Roland (2004) Pressures achieved in such quenches are, numerically, only a fraction of the elastic moduli, again implying the condition (S29) is not met in such experiments.

A very contrasting situation is presented by rigid particles, which are intrinsically classical effectively implying TD=0subscript𝑇𝐷0T_{D}=0. Here the typical vibrational displacement can be made arbitrarily small while the bulk modulus can be arbitrarily large. Thus the buckling instability occurs when:

K~≃(9​π/2)​μ~f,similar-to-or-equals~𝐾9𝜋2subscript~𝜇𝑓\widetilde{K}\simeq(9\pi/2)\widetilde{\mu}_{f}, (S30)

up to a factor of order one. The solution of the above equation for monodisperse hard spheres is shown as the red solid line in Fig. 4, where we assumed the Poisson ratio of the equilibrated liquid is density-independent, see details in the Supporting Information. We observe that the “buckling instability” line merges rather smoothly with the string-spinodal line. Clearly, sufficiently close to the spinodal the argument leading to Eq. (S28) is not externally consistent, nor would the string and buckling instabilities be easily distinguishable in this case.

Eq. (S28) can be applied to regions of size N𝑁N larger than the immediate coordination shell of a single particle. Assuming the vibrational displacement is distributed evenly across the region, one obtains a more general statement:

K~≳μ~f​N,greater-than-or-equivalent-to~𝐾subscript~𝜇𝑓𝑁\widetilde{K}\gtrsim\widetilde{\mu}_{f}N, (S31)

c.f. Eq. (S30), and we are continuing working with rigid particles. The above equation implies that the “buckling instability” line in Figs. 2 and 4 corresponds with a threshold limit for the quantity K~~𝐾\widetilde{K} above which such symmetry breakings that could occur within a continuous spectrum of lengthscales. At the threshold, the buckling events occur only very locally, viz., at a single cage size, as just discussed. Above the threshold, on the other hand, the events could become significantly more extended. Indeed, in view of Eqs. (4) and (5), Eq. (S31) yields the following scaling relations:

L∝p2/3∝T−2/3,proportional-to𝐿superscript𝑝23proportional-tosuperscript𝑇23L\propto p^{2/3}\propto T^{-2/3}, (S32)

where L∝N1/3proportional-to𝐿superscript𝑁13L\propto N^{1/3} is the physical extent of the “buckled” region. One may say that the diverging length scale above is that corresponding to jamming a macroscopically stable aperiodic crystal. To avoid confusion, we note that observable consequences of the growing correlation length (S32) will be somewhat limited since the spatial concentration of the so jammed modes goes as 1/L3∝1/p2∝T2proportional-to1superscript𝐿31superscript𝑝2proportional-tosuperscript𝑇21/L^{3}\propto 1/p^{2}\propto T^{2}. Interestingly, the corresponding entropy per unit volume: L−3​ln⁡2superscript𝐿32L^{-3}\ln 2—assuming there are two choices for an individual symmetry breaking event—scales quadratically with temperature:

S/V≃T2​μ~f​ρ3​ln⁡2A​p2,similar-to-or-equals𝑆𝑉superscript𝑇2subscript~𝜇𝑓superscript𝜌32𝐴superscript𝑝2S/V\simeq T^{2}\frac{\widetilde{\mu}_{f}\rho^{3}\ln 2}{Ap^{2}}, (S33)

and likewise for the corresponding heat capacity C=T​(∂S/∂T)𝐶𝑇𝑆𝑇C=T(\partial S/\partial T). This is a slower scaling than Debye’s T3superscript𝑇3T^{3} law for the phonon heat capacity. (For rigid objects, the comparison must be made with the T𝑇T-independent Dulong-Petit law.) In any event, the correlation length L𝐿L will stop growing when the strings begin to nucleate, of course, while removing the above contribution to the total entropy of the sample. At the same time, of all of the buckling-induced jamming will be removed.

V Slope of a configurationally-adiabatic p−V𝑝𝑉p-V curve relative to its value for the equilibrium isotherm, and its relation to the liquid’s fragility: A qualitative discussion

First we focus exclusively on the configurational degrees of freedom. For any degree of freedom, the adiabatic compressibility is always less than its isothermal counterpart. Landau and Lifshitz (1980) Insofar as one may regard the configurational degrees of freedom as decoupled from the vibrations, we may use the standard formula Landau and Lifshitz (1980) (∂V/∂p)S/(∂V/∂p)T=Cv/Cpsubscript𝑉𝑝𝑆subscript𝑉𝑝𝑇subscript𝐶𝑣subscript𝐶𝑝(\partial V/\partial p)_{S}/(\partial V/\partial p)_{T}=C_{v}/C_{p} to estimate the ratio of the adiabatic and isothermal bulk moduli in terms of the configurational parts of the heat capacity:

(∂p/∂V)Sc(conf)(∂p/∂V)T(conf)=Δ​CpΔ​Cv,subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(conf)subscript𝑆𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(conf)𝑇Δsubscript𝐶𝑝Δsubscript𝐶𝑣\frac{(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(conf)}}_{S_{c}}}{(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(conf)}}_{T}}=\frac{\Delta C_{p}}{\Delta C_{v}}, (S34)

where “(conf)” refers to “configurational” and it is understood that (∂p/∂V)S(conf)≡(∂p/∂V)Sc(conf)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(conf)𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(conf)subscript𝑆𝑐(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(conf)}}_{S}\equiv(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(conf)}}_{S_{c}}. In writing down Eq. (S34), we assume that the bulk moduli corresponding to the configurational and vibrational degrees of freedom are additive, not the compressibilities:

(∂p/∂V)=(∂p/∂V)(conf)+(∂p/∂V)(vibr)𝑝𝑉superscript𝑝𝑉(conf)superscript𝑝𝑉(vibr)(\partial p/\partial V)=(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(conf)}}+(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(vibr)}} (S35)

The analogy is with two springs that are connected in parallel, not consecutively.

The ratio on the r.h.s. in Eq. (S34) can be estimated using an approximate connection with the fragility index mfrsuperscript𝑚frm^{\text{fr}}: Xia and Wolynes (2000) Δ​C∝mfrproportional-toΔ𝐶superscript𝑚fr\Delta C\propto m^{\text{fr}} and the approximate relation between fragility coefficient at constant pressure and volume: Rabochiy and Lubchenko (2012a); Lubchenko (2015) mpfr≃mVfr+30similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑝frsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑉fr30m_{p}^{\text{fr}}\simeq m_{V}^{\text{fr}}+30. Hence,

(∂p/∂V)Sc(conf)(∂p/∂V)T(conf)≃mpfrmVfr=mVfr+30mVfr>1.similar-to-or-equalssubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(conf)subscript𝑆𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(conf)𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑝frsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑉frsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑉fr30superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑉fr1\frac{(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(conf)}}_{S_{c}}}{(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(conf)}}_{T}}\simeq\frac{m_{p}^{\text{fr}}}{m_{V}^{\text{fr}}}=\frac{m_{V}^{\text{fr}}+30}{m_{V}^{\text{fr}}}>1. (S36)

Finally, Eqs. (S35) and (S36) imply that

(∂p/∂V)Sc(∂p/∂V)Tsubscript𝑝𝑉subscript𝑆𝑐subscript𝑝𝑉𝑇\displaystyle\frac{(\partial p/\partial V)_{S_{c}}}{(\partial p/\partial V)_{T}} =(∂p/∂V)Sc(conf)+(∂p/∂V)Sc(vibr)(∂p/∂V)T(conf)+(∂p/∂V)T(vibr)absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(conf)subscript𝑆𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(vibr)subscript𝑆𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(conf)𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑉(vibr)𝑇\displaystyle=\frac{(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(conf)}}_{S_{c}}+(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(vibr)}}_{S_{c}}}{(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(conf)}}_{T}+(\partial p/\partial V)^{\text{(vibr)}}_{T}} (S37)

The mVfr/mpfrsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑉frsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑝frm_{V}^{\text{fr}}/m_{p}^{\text{fr}} ratio approaches zero for the strongest known substances but only marginally smaller than one for very fragile substances. Casalini and Roland (2005) Thus we expect inequality (S39) and, hence, the slope disparity between the EOS and sc=constsubscript𝑠𝑐consts_{c}=\text{const} quenches to be greater for stronger substances.
